Comment 3: 
I understand. But go has to visit a file containing a
// +build ignore

(or any other unsatisfied build constraint) anyway, as it doesn't know in advance if the
file has to be considered for the build or not. Now if this file, which may be part of
the build but should be ignored by the constraint, is newer than the executable, the
executable should be rebuilt. I don't see the necessity to save this information in a
segment of the executable (which would indeed be an enormous task)

I can live with go clean -t either, and such things don't happen to often anyway.
